step1.sentence: The hiring manager used a skills test to weed out candidates who weren't qualified for the position.

step2.story: The committee reviewed hundreds of applications to weed out anyone who didn't meet the basic requirements. After a long afternoon, they had narrowed the pile down to just twenty promising candidates.

step3.story: Every spring, the head coach ran new recruits through a grueling two-week training camp designed to weed out those who lacked the commitment to compete at the highest level. The drills were relentless — early mornings, late nights, and barely a moment to rest. Some players quietly packed their bags and left without a word. Those who stayed emerged tougher, more focused, and genuinely hungry to prove themselves. By the final day, the roster felt leaner but far more unified, each remaining player knowing exactly what they had signed up for.

meaning.literalMeaningKo: 정원에서 잡초(weed)를 뽑아내듯, 무리 중에서 불필요하거나 부적합한 것을 골라내다.
meaning.realUsageKo: 채용, 선발, 교육 등의 과정에서 기준에 미치지 못하는 사람이나 요소를 제거할 때 널리 쓰인다. '걸러내다', '추려내다'와 같은 의미로 사용된다.
meaning.etymologyKo: 농사에서 유래한 표현으로, 작물 사이의 잡초(weed)를 뽑아 제거하는(out) 행위에서 비유적 의미가 파생되었다.
meaning.nuanceKo: 단순한 제거보다는 '기준을 세우고 체계적으로 걸러낸다'는 뉘앙스가 강하다. 다소 냉정하고 선택적인 판단이 개입됨을 암시한다.
meaning.shortExampleEn: The editor weeded out all the redundant paragraphs before submitting the final draft.
meaning.shortExampleKo: 편집자는 최종 원고를 제출하기 전에 중복된 단락들을 모두 솎아냈다.
